comment.body: @Wire: An old film from 1995.
ZeroNet is not Tor.
Ayaya!

`/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit`
`/ZeroMedia.bit`
You are just one slash way.
There is no private data in the P2P architecture, since every part of what you see is shared by everyone. The content of ZeroMail is also shared by everyone, but encrypted.
Freenet, IPFS...
nofish
Bwoi Analytic
@Sick Bird: Bwoi Analytic is planned, but the [site](/bwoi.bit) has not been updated since the end of last month.
Why not add a Let's Encrypt certificate?
@RiotPulv: I don't think you have to include your port in the certificate. (e.g. https://5.101.103.222:43110/ https://bit.no.com:43110)
ZeroRevision: Free, Decentralized and Anonymous essay proofread service.
Active probing of Chinese National Firewall (?)
A LOT OF people use this.
@Bravo: This is the Firefox iframe bug. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1293316
You can use ZeroNet in Tor Browser to register for a ZeroID.

If ignoring a complaint makes the whole server go down, I would choose to take down that .bit address. (Before deleting it, put it onto other proxies).


but you can also download another copy of ZeroNet onto your VPS and configure that copy of ZeroNet to always use Tor.
@Border0464fred: That Q9 thing seems to be a commercial sh*t made by a Hong Kong company. MRL's proxy is in Japan. Both places comply to DMCA requests.
GNURoot
When you are not using `target='_top'`, the link will be opened in ZeroNet's sandbox. Using `target='_blank'` will not make the GitHub page escape the sandbox.
